titleStmt.title: Transcription 1: The Book of Deer (CUL I.i.6.32)

availability.p: For internal use by the Faclair na Gàidhlig/DASG projects.

note.p: A foundation legend of the monastery of Deer (mod. Aberdeenshire) and a set of property records, in Middle Gaelic, added to the Book of Deer, a late first millenium Latin Gospel Book produced under Irish influence somewhere in the north of Britain. The Gaelic texts were almost certainly inscribed at Deer. They are in Middle Gaelic but with features distinctive to Scottish Gaelic. In addition, there are two short specimens of Old Gaelic within the Gospel Book proper of less certain provenance.

msContents.summary: The Book of Deer proper contains at least excerpts of all four Gospels, as well as an office for the visitation of the sick and the Apostles Creed. Gaelic texts added to the manuscript later (in the late 11th or early 12th century) concern the foundation of the monastery of Deer and its property claims.

filiation.p: No other versions of this text are known.
No other versions of this text are known.

msItem.title: Property Records (2)
msItem.incipit: Gartnait mac cannech ocus éte ingengillemíchel ...

filiation.p: No other versions of this text are known.

msItem.title: Office for the Visitation of the Sick: Old Gaelic Rubric

filiation.p: No other versions of this textual material are known.

note.p: This largely complies with the norms of late Old Gaelic in grammar and phonology. The use of a conjugated preposition in place of an infixed pronoun at fol. 28v15 hints at the later part of the Old Gaelic period (in line with the estimated period in which the manuscript was created, 850×1000).

titleStmt.title: Office for the Visitation of the Sick: Old Gaelic Rubric

filiation.p: No other versions of this textual material are known.

note.p: Like the rubric in the Office for the Visitation of the Sick (text 7), this specimen largely complies with the norms of late Old Gaelic in grammar and phonology.

physDesc.p: The information below is from Zutshi and Binski (no date).

foliation.p: Various; modern foliation used in this digital edition

condition.p: Mostly very good; only a few individual characters are obscured by isolated spots of damage. Text 2 may have been partially erased to make way for Text 3 (Forsyth, Broun, and Clancy 2008: 138) but what is left is perfectly legible.

layoutDesc.p: Main text area is 108 mm×71 mm, ruled in hard point. Of the Gaelic Notes, Texts 1-4 are the main texts on the pages they occupy, while texts 5, 6, and part of 2 are written into the margins (side, head, and foot) of the Latin main text. Text 7 consists of two specimens of Gaelic embedded within the Latin main text.

provenance.p: The origins of the Gospel Book are ultimately unknown but it is thought most likely that it was produced somewhere in what is now Scotland, under Irish artistic influence, between around 850 and 1000. The Gaelic Notes are in a range of hands but the texts all seem to date from the early 12th century; Text 3 (fol.4r.17) specifies the 8th year of the reign of David I (1131×1132). They were almost certainly written at Deer, in what is now Aberdeenshire, given that this house is the focus of all the texts and all the transactions are in Deer's favour. They were probably also written down during this period.

refsDecl.p: References are to manuscript folio and line number (the <pb> and <lb> closed elements).

langUsage.p: The predominant influence on the language of the Gaelic notes in the Book of Deer is Middle Gaelic. However, it is agreed that the texts contain numerous deviations from the norms of Middle Gaelic as observed in Irish manuscripts. Although sometimes labelled scribal errors (Jackson 1972), they are increasingly recognised as phoneticisms and other dialectal features (Ó Maolalaigh 2008b). This means that the Gaelic Notes are in fact an important source for the history of Scottish Gaelic, especially in the north-east. It is also significant that the five hands and six texts involved share a lot of these dialectal and stylistic features, suggesting that this is is a literary register based on or influenced by a local dialect.

Many of the distinctive linguistic features of the notes are to do with pronunciation. Phonetic "mis-spellings" repeatedly correspond with developments later attested in Scottish Gaelic (most fully discussed by Ó Maolalaigh 2008b), such as breaking of vowels, epenthetic vowels, a distinctive system of eclipsis, and the merger of final unstressed -ch and -gh. A few Scottish morphological features are also attested, like the growing predominance of the dative at the expense of the accusative.

Another distinctive feature of the Gaelic Notes, as compared to central medieval Irish manuscripts, is the more extensive use of accents, often over consonants as well as over vowels. Again, while it is easy to dismiss this as incompetence, Ó Maolalaigh has shown that it may well constitute a thought-out orthographic system (Ó Maolalaigh 2008a). Further research is needed, to determine whether this is particular to the scribes of the Gaelic Notes or whether it or something like it is employed elsewhere.

It should be stressed, however, that the Gaelic Notes also contain numerous distinctively Middle Gaelic features (with roots in Old Gaelic). For example, deuterotonic conjunct verbs are still used, "ro-" still appears as a preverbal particle, and there are instances of adjectival declension.
All in all, the Gaelic Notes show the influence of both Middle Gaelic, as known from Irish sources, and local Scottish dialect, bound together by technically adept and innovative literate personnel.

Finally, perhaps on account of their high status setting, the Gaelic Notes employ a very restricted range of abbreviations, although the small group that are used are used quite frequently. Lenition dots or ticks, n-strokes, and standard abbreviations of "mac" and "ocus" are the most frequently encountered.

revisionDesc.change: Created marked up text and header.
